item.title: RunningTracker
item.author: paolo.enrico@gmail.com (home)
item.description:
This project is a RESTful API to track amateur running activities.

I did it because I am an amateur runner.

So, the API itself was not a work challenge, it was more a fun project to do in my free time. But I also took the opportunity to perform all tests I know and provided a detailed explanation of each in the README in Github.

If you have something to share or discuss about the project, please feel free to reach out and we can have a chat.

item.title: SignalR
item.author: paolo.enrico@gmail.com (home)
item.description:
This project utilizes SignalR to send real-time data to one or more clients via WebSockets. In this example, we are streaming data from a SQL Server database to clients..

Instead of making a request/response paginated “Web API, we decided to use SignalR in this specific project and the Consumer handles the data received. It was applied into a massive data scenario, where we could inquire the database for all orders confirmed by the stock exchange to evaluate some specific scenarios.

item.title: Kafka
item.author: paolo.enrico@gmail.com (home)
item.description:
We were facing a challenge as a team to move a legacy application to a microservices architecture. The application was built using .NET and was running on a monolithic architecture. We decided to use Kafka as our message broker to decouple the services and allow for asynchronous communication between them.

This application was responsible for retrieving millions of operations on a daily basis and to complete all calculations in a reasonable time for each associated office and financial advisors.
